section: quantumcomm.py examples/esa2/quantumcomm.py Go to the documentation of this file.00001 # See original code at 00002 # https://optimize.esa.int/challenge/spoc-2-quantum-communications-constellations/About 00003 # https://optimize.esa.int/challenge/spoc-2-quantum-communications-constellations/p/quantum-communications-constellations 00004 # 00005 # Changes: 00006 # - Factor 30 speedup using numba and igraph 00007 # - Added competitive algorithms 00008 # - See corresponding tutorial 00009 # https://github.com/dietmarwo/fast-cma-es/blob/master/tutorials/ESAChallenge.adoc 00010 00011 # Requires pykep which needs python 3.8, 00012 # Create an python 3.8 environment: 00013 00014 # mamba create -n env38 python=3.8 00015 # conda activate env38 00016 00017 # Install dependencies: 00018 00019 # mamba install pykep 00020 # mamba install pygmo 00021 # pip install networkx 00022 # pip install sgp4 00023 # pip install seaborn 00024 # pip install matplotlib 00025 # pip install igraph 00026 # pip install pymoo 00027 00028 # Tested using https://docs.conda.io/en/main/miniconda.html on Linux Mint 21.2 00029 00030 # Basic imports 00031 import pykep as pk 00032 import pygmo as pg 00033 import numpy as np 00034 import scipy 00035 import os, time 00036 from matplotlib import pyplot as plt 00037 00038 import sys 00039 from loguru import logger 00040 00041 logger.remove() 00042 logger.add(sys.stdout, format="{time:HH:mm:ss.SS} | {process} | {level} | {message}", level="INFO") 00043 logger.add("log_{time}.txt", format="{time:HH:mm:ss.SS} | {process} | {level} | {message}", level="INFO") 00044 00045 import seaborn as sns 00046 # SGP4 - we use SPG4 to propagate orbits around New Mars as a proxy 00047 # for a plausible orbital positions propagator around a habitable planet 00048 from sgp4.api import Satrec, SatrecArray 00049 from sgp4.api import WGS72 00050 00051 # Networkx 00052 import igraph as ig # for speed 00053 import networkx as nx 00054 00055 # Static data 00056 def get_mothership_satellites(): 00057 """Construct array of mothership orbital elements 00058 (the TLEs of actual Earth-orbiting satellites below are used as a proxy for 00059 plausible orbital dynamics around a habitable planet) 00060 """ 00061 mothership_tles = [ 00062 [ 00063 "1 39634U 14016A 22349.82483685 .00000056 00000-0 21508-4 0 9992", 00064 "2 39634 98.1813 354.7934 0001199 83.3324 276.7993 14.59201191463475" 00065 ], 00066 [ 00067 "1 26400U 00037A 00208.84261022 +.00077745 +00000-0 +00000-0 0 9995", 00068 "2 26400 051.5790 297.6001 0012791 171.3037 188.7763 15.69818870002328" 00069 ], 00070 [ 00071 "1 36508U 10013A 22349.92638064 .00000262 00000-0 64328-4 0 9992", 00072 "2 36508 92.0240 328.0627 0004726 21.3451 338.7953 14.51905975672463" 00073 ], 00074 [ 00075 "1 40128U 14050A 22349.31276420 -.00000077 00000-0 00000-0 0 9995", 00076 "2 40128 50.1564 325.0733 1614819 130.5958 244.6527 1.85519534 54574" 00077 ], 00078 [ 00079 "1 49810U 21116B 23065.71091236 -.00000083 00000+0 00000+0 0 9998", 00080 "2 49810 57.2480 13.9949 0001242 301.4399 239.8890 1.70475839 7777" 00081 ], 00082 [ 00083 "1 44878U 19092F 22349.75758852 .00015493 00000-0 00000-0 0 9998", 00084 "2 44878 97.4767 172.6133 0012815 68.6990 291.5614 15.23910904165768" 00085 ], 00086 [ 00087 "1 04382U 70034A 22349.88472104 .00001138 00000-0 18306-3 0 9999", 00088 "2 04382 68.4200 140.9159 1043234 48.2283 320.3286 13.08911192477908" 00089 ] 00090 ] 00091 00092 # Assembling the list of Satrec motherships 00093 motherships = [] 00094 for tle in mothership_tles: 00095 motherships.append(Satrec.twoline2rv(tle[0], tle[1])) 00096 return motherships 00097 00098 from numba import njit 00099 00100 @njit(fastmath=True) 00101 def line_of_sight(r1,r2): 00102 """Given two position vectors returns the distance of the line of sight to the origin 00103 00104 Args: 00105 r1 (numpy array): first point 00106 r2 (numpy array): second point 00107 """ 00108 denom = np.linalg.norm(r2-r1) 00109 if denom < 1e-6: 00110 # if r1 ~= r2, it will return the norm of r1 00111 return np.linalg.norm(r1) 00112 else: 00113 r21 = (r2-r1) / denom 00114 h1 = np.dot(r1,r21) 00115 arg = np.linalg.norm(r1)**2 - h1**2 00116 # We check for a positive arg in case r1 and r2 are near collinearity 00117 return np.sqrt(arg) if arg > 1e-6 else 0.0 00118 00119 @njit(fastmath=True) 00120 def zenith_angle(src, dst): 00121 """Computes the cosine of the zenith angle (theta_z) of the LOS between source and destination node 00122 00123 Args: 00124 src (numpy array, N_r x 3): rover x, y, z positions 00125 dst (numpy array, N_s x 3): mothership x, y, z positions 00126 00127 Returns: 00128 float: cosine of the zenith angle 00129 """ 00130 dpos = dst - src 00131 if np.linalg.norm(dpos) < 1e-6: 00132 cos_theta_z = 0 00133 else: 00134 cos_theta_z = np.dot(dpos, src) / (np.linalg.norm(dpos) * np.linalg.norm(src)) 00135 return cos_theta_z 00136 00137 @njit(fastmath=True) 00138 def qkd_metric(idx, src, dst, cos_theta_z, eta, eps_z, n_rovers): 00139 """Computes the edge weight according to QKD probabilities 00140 00141 Args: 00142 idx (int): index of node in the graph 00143 src (numpy array, 1x3): position of source node 00144 dst (numpy array, 1x3): position of destination node 00145 cos_theta_z (float): cosine of the zenith angle of qkd link 00146 eta (int): satellite quality indicator for corresponding constellation 00147 00148 Returns: 00149 float: edge weight 00150 float: communications link distance between src and dst 00151 """ 00152 edge_weight = -np.log(eta) # constellation quality score 00153 d_link = np.linalg.norm(src - dst) # distance of communications link 00154 edge_weight += 2 * np.log(d_link) # final edge weight 00155 if edge_weight < 0: 00156 # Safeguard: whenever this happens, the collision-avoidance constraint is 00157 # also not satisfied. Nevertheless, we must return a value for the edge weight 00158 # to ensure that the fitness does not throw (a negative valued edge would also 00159 # imply the non-existence of a shortest path) 00160 edge_weight = 1e3 00161 00162 if idx <= n_rovers: 00163 if cos_theta_z >= eps_z: # Apply max zenith angle constraint to mothership-rover link 00164 edge_weight += 1.0 / np.sin(np.pi / 2 - np.arccos(cos_theta_z)) 00165 else: 00166 edge_weight = 0 00167 return edge_weight, d_link 00168 00169 @njit(fastmath=True) 00170 def get_adjmatrix(pos, ep_idx, eta, num_w1_sats, LOS, N, eps_z, n_rovers): 00171 adjmatrix = np.zeros((N, N)) 00172 d_min = np.inf 00173 for i in range(N): 00174 for j in range(i): 00175 # Ensure there is LOS 00176 los = line_of_sight(pos[i, ep_idx, :], pos[j, ep_idx, :]) 00177 cos_theta_z = zenith_angle(pos[i, ep_idx, :], pos[j, ep_idx, :]) 00178 if los >= LOS or cos_theta_z > 0: 00179 # Eta based on j because it is the destination satellite in the link 00180 eta_j = eta[0] if j < num_w1_sats else eta[1] 00181 adjmatrix[i,j], d_link = \ 00182 qkd_metric(N-i, pos[i, ep_idx, :], pos[j, ep_idx, :], cos_theta_z, eta_j, eps_z, n_rovers) 00183 if d_link < d_min: 00184 d_min = d_link 00185 adjmatrix[j,i] = adjmatrix[i,j] 00186 return adjmatrix, d_min 00187 00188 @njit(fastmath=True) 00189 def construct_rover_pos(lambda0, phi0, n_rovers, jds, R_p, w_p): 00190 """Computes the position of the rovers at time t based on the initial latitude and longitude 00191 00192 Args: 00193 lambda0 (float, N_r x 1): initial latitudes of the rovers 00194 phi0 (float, N_r x 1): initial longitudes of the rovers 00195 00196 Returns: 00197 float, n_rovers x n_epochs x 3: rover x, y, z positions 00198 """ 00199 pos_r = np.zeros((n_rovers, jds.shape[0], 3)) 00200 time_range = (jds - jds[0]) * 24 * 3600 # in seconds 00201 for i, t in enumerate(time_range): 00202 pos_r[:, i, 0] = R_p * np.cos(lambda0) * np.cos(phi0 + w_p * t) # x 00203 pos_r[:, i, 1] = R_p * np.cos(lambda0) * np.sin(phi0 + w_p * t) # y 00204 pos_r[:, i, 2] = R_p * np.sin(lambda0) # z 00205 return pos_r 00206 00207 class constellation_udp: 00208 """A Pygmo compatible UDP (User Defined Problem) representing the constellation design problem for SpOC 2023. 00209 00210 Two Walker constellations are defined in a mixint chromosome: 00211 x = [a1,ei,i1,w1,eta1] + [a2,e2,i2,w2,eta2] + [S1,P1,F1] + [S2,P2,F2] + [r1,r2,r3,r4] 00212 00213 The constellations must relay information between 7 motherships in orbit and 4 rovers on the surface of New Mars 00214 """ 00215 def __init__(self): 00216 """Constructor""" 00217 00218 # Define the time grid over which to optimize the communications network 00219 self._t0 = 10000 # starting epoch in mjd2000 00220 self.n_epochs = 11 # number of epochs in time grid to consider 00221 self._duration = 10 # difference between the first and last epoch considered in years 00222 jd0, fr = pk.epoch(self._t0, 'mjd2000').jd, 0.0 # reference Julian date 00223 self.jds = np.linspace(jd0, jd0 + self._duration * 365.25, self.n_epochs) # time grid in JD 00224 self.frs = self.jds * fr # date fractions (defaults to 0) 00225 00226 # Reference epoch for SGP4 is 1949 December 31 00:00 UT 00227 self.ep_ref = pk.epoch_from_iso_string("19491231T000000") 00228 00229 # SGP4-ready mothership satellites 00230 mothership_satellites = get_mothership_satellites() 00231 self.pos_m = self.construct_mothership_pos(SatrecArray(mothership_satellites)) 00232 self.n_motherships = len(mothership_satellites) 00233 00234 # Latitudes and longitudes of rovers 00235 rovers_db_path = os.path.join(".", "data", "spoc2", "constellations", "rovers.txt") 00236 self.rovers_db = np.loadtxt(rovers_db_path) 00237 self.lambdas = self.rovers_db[:, 0] # latitudes 00238 self.phis = self.rovers_db[:, 1] # longitudes 00239 self._min_rover_dist = 3000 # minimum inter-rover distance (km) 00240 self.n_rovers = 4 00241 00242 # Minimum line-of-sight parameter (km) 00243 # Radius amplification factor: 1.05 00244 self.LOS = 1.05 * pk.EARTH_RADIUS / 1000.0 00245 # Radius of the New-Mars planet (km) 00246 self.R_p = pk.EARTH_RADIUS / 1000.0 00247 # Angular velocity of New Mars (rad/s) 00248 self.w_p = 7.29e-5 # 2 * pi / (23 hours 56 minutes 4 seconds) 00249 # Threshold zenith angle constraint for rover-sat link (rad) 00250 self._zenith_angle = np.pi / 3 00251 self.eps_z = np.cos(self._zenith_angle) 00252 # Minimum inter-satellite distance (km) 00253 self._min_sat_dist = 50 00254 00255 def get_bounds(self): 00256 """Get bounds for the decision variables. 00257 00258 Returns: 00259 Tuple of lists: bounds for the decision variables. 00260 """ 00261 lb = [1.06, 0., 0., 0., 1.0] + [2.0, 0., 0., 0., 1.0] + [4, 2, 0] + [4, 2, 0] + [0, 0, 0, 0] 00262 #ub = [1.8, 0.02, np.pi, 2*np.pi, 1000.0] + [3.5, 0.1, np.pi, 2*np.pi, 1000.0] + [10, 10, 9] + [10, 10, 9] + [99, 99, 99, 99] 00263 # we adapt the boundaries so that they work with a continuous optimizer 00264 ub = [1.8, 0.02, np.pi, 2*np.pi, 1000.0] + [3.5, 0.1, np.pi, 2*np.pi, 1000.0] + \ 00265 [10.9999, 10.9999, 9.9999] + [10.9999, 10.9999, 9.9999] + [99.9999, 99.9999, 99.9999, 99.9999] 00266 return (lb, ub) 00267 00268 def get_ints(self): 00269 return np.array([False]*10 + [True]*10) 00270 00271 def get_nix(self): 00272 """Get number of integer variables. 00273 00274 Returns: 00275 int: number of integer variables. 00276 """ 00277 return 6 + 4 00278 00279 def get_nobj(self): 00280 """Get number of objectives. 00281 00282 Returns: 00283 int: the number of objectives 00284 """ 00285 return 2 00286 00287 def get_nic(self): 00288 """Get number of inequality constraints. 00289 00290 Returns: 00291 int: the number of constraints 00292 """ 00293 return 2 00294 00295 def get_rover_constraint(self, lambda0, phi0): 00296 """Evaluate the rover constraint (minimum distance between any two rovers) 00297 00298 Args: 00299 lambda0 (float, N_r x 1): latitudes of the rovers 00300 phi0 (float, N_r x 1): longitudes of the rovers 00301 00302 Returns 00303 float: the difference between the actual and allowable minimum distance between rovers 00304 """ 00305 # Compute rover positions on the planet 00306 pos = np.zeros((self.n_rovers, 3)) 00307 pos[:, 0] = np.sin(lambda0) * np.cos(phi0) 00308 pos[:, 1] = np.cos(lambda0) * np.cos(phi0) 00309 pos[:, 2] = np.sin(phi0) 00310 def safe_arccos(u, v): 00311 inner_product = np.dot(u, v) 00312 if inner_product > 1: 00313 return 0 00314 if inner_product < -1: 00315 return np.pi 00316 return np.arccos(inner_product) 00317 d = scipy.spatial.distance.cdist(pos, pos, lambda u, v: pk.EARTH_RADIUS/1000 * safe_arccos(u, v)) 00318 d = d + np.diag([np.inf]*4) 00319 min_d = np.min(d) 00320 # Will be negative if min(d) is larger than the min allowable inter-rover distance 00321 return self._min_rover_dist - min_d, min_d 00322 00323 def get_sat_constraint(self, d_min): 00324 """Evaluate the satellite constraint (minimum distance between any two satellites) 00325 00326 Args: 00327 d_min (float): the minimum distance between any two satellites at any epoch 00328 00329 Returns: 00330 float: the difference between the actual and allowable minimum distance between satellites 00331 """ 00332 # Will be negative if d_min is larger than the min allowable inter-satellite distance 00333 return self._min_sat_dist - d_min 00334 00335 00336 def generate_walker(self, S,P,F,a,e,incl,w,t0): 00337 """Generates a Walker constallation as a SatrecArray 00338 00339 Args: 00340 S (int): number of satellites per plane 00341 P (int): number of planes 00342 F (int): spacing parameter (i.e. if 2 phasing repeats each 2 planes) 00343 a (float): semi-major axis 00344 e (float): eccentricity 00345 incl (float): inclination 00346 w (float): argument of perigee 00347 t0 (float): epoch 00348 00349 Returns: 00350 SatrecArray: satellites ready to be SGP4 propagated 00351 """ 00352 walker_l = [] 00353 mean_motion = np.sqrt(pk.MU_EARTH/a**3/pk.EARTH_RADIUS**3) 00354 # planes 00355 for i in range(P): 00356 #satellites 00357 for j in range(S): 00358 satellite = Satrec() 00359 satellite.sgp4init( 00360 WGS72, # gravity model 00361 'i', # 'a' = old AFSPC mode, 'i' = improved mode 00362 j + i*S, # satnum: Satellite number 00363 t0-self.ep_ref.mjd2000, # epoch: days since 1949 December 31 00:00 UT 00364 0.0, # bstar: drag coefficient (1/earth radii) - 3.8792e-05 00365 0.0, # ndot: ballistic coefficient (revs/day) 00366 0.0, # nddot: mean motion 2nd derivative (revs/day^3) 00367 e, # ecco: eccentricity 00368 w, # argpo: argument of perigee (radians) 00369 incl, # inclo: inclination (radians) 00370 2*np.pi/P/S*F*i+2.*np.pi/S*j, # mo: mean anomaly (radians) 00371 mean_motion*60, # no_kozai: mean motion (radians/minute) 00372 2.*np.pi/P*i # nodeo: R.A. of ascending node (radians) 00373 ) 00374 walker_l.append(satellite) 00375 # Creating the vectorized list 00376 return SatrecArray(walker_l) 00377 00378 def build_graph(self, ep_idx, pos, num_w1_sats, eta): 00379 """Builds a networkx graph from the satellite positions. Links are weighted via a "QKD-inspired metric 00380 and only exist when motherships/constellation satellites/rovers have line-of-sight 00381 00382 Args: 00383 ep_idx (int): idx of the epoch in the time grid 00384 pos (numpy array 3xN): position vector of the satellites 00385 num_w1_sats (int): number of satellites in the first Walker constellation 00386 eta (tuple): satellite quality indicator for each Walker constellation 00387 00388 Returns: 00389 igraph graph: nodes are motherships/Walker satellites/rovers; links are distances when there is LOS 00390 """ 00391 N = pos[:, ep_idx, :].shape[0] # number of vertices 00392 adjmatrix, d_min = get_adjmatrix(pos, ep_idx, eta, num_w1_sats, self.LOS, N, self.eps_z, self.n_rovers) 00393 g = ig.Graph.Adjacency((adjmatrix > 0).tolist()) 00394 g.es['weight'] = adjmatrix[adjmatrix.nonzero()] 00395 return g, adjmatrix, d_min 00396 00397 def average_shortest_path(self, G, src, dst): 00398 """Computes the average shortest path length between the source and destination *partitions* of nodes in the graph *G* 00399 (the source is assumed to be the motherships and the destination the rovers) 00400 00401 Args: 00402 G (networkx graph): The graph 00403 src (int): the number of motherships (to be used as a negative index in G) 00404 dst (int): the number of rovers (to be used as a negative index in G) 00405 00406 Returns: 00407 float: average shortest path 00408 """ 00409 n_nodes = G.vcount() 00410 src0 = n_nodes - src - dst 00411 dst0 = n_nodes - dst 00412 sp = np.array(G.distances(list(range(src0, src0+src)), \ 00413 list(range(dst0, dst0+dst)), weights=G.es["weight"])) 00414 return np.mean(sp) 00415 00416 def construct_walkers(self, x): 00417 """Generates two Walker constellations according to specifications 00418 00419 Args: 00420 x (list): chromosome describing the New Mars communications infrastructure 00421 00422 Returns: 00423 SatrecArray: Walker1 constellation satellites ready to be SGP4 propagated 00424 SatrecArray: Walker2 constellation satellites ready to be SGP4 propagated 00425 """ 00426 # Parse the chromosome 00427 a1,e1,i1,w1,_,a2,e2,i2,w2,_,S1,P1,F1,S2,P2,F2,_,_,_,_ = x 00428 # Construct the 1st walker constellation as a SatrecArray 00429 walker1 = self.generate_walker(int(S1),int(P1),int(F1),a1,e1,i1,w1,self._t0) 00430 # Construct the 2nd walker constellation as a SatrecArray 00431 walker2 = self.generate_walker(int(S2),int(P2),int(F2),a2,e2,i2,w2,self._t0) 00432 return walker1, walker2 00433 00434 def construct_mothership_pos(self, motherships): 00435 """Computes the position of the motherships over a predefined time grid 00436 00437 Args: 00438 motherships (SatrecArray): mothership satellites ready to be SGP4 propagated 00439 00440 Returns: 00441 float, n_motherships x n_epochs x 3: mothership x, y, z positions 00442 """ 00443 00444 err, pos, _ = motherships.sgp4(self.jds, self.frs) 00445 # Check propagation went well 00446 if not np.all(err == 0): 00447 raise ValueError("The motherships cannot be propagated succesfully on the defined time grid") 00448 return pos 00449 00450 def construct_pos(self, walker1, walker2, pos_r): 00451 """Construct cumulative position of Walker satellites, motherships and rovers 00452 00453 Args: 00454 walker1 (SatrecArray): Walker1 constellation satellites ready to be SGP4 propagated 00455 walker2 (SatrecArray): Walker2 constellation satellites ready to be SGP4 propagated 00456 pos_r (float, n_rovers x n_epochs x 3): rover x, y, z positions 00457 00458 Returns: 00459 float, (S1xP1 + S2xP2 + n_motherships + n_rovers) x n_epochs x 3: overall position vector 00460 """ 00461 # Compute ephemerides for Walker1 satellites at all epochs) 00462 err_w1, pos_w1, _ = walker1.sgp4(self.jds, self.frs) 00463 # Compute ephemerides for Walker2 satellites at all epochs) 00464 err_w2, pos_w2, _ = walker2.sgp4(self.jds, self.frs) 00465 # Check propagation went well 00466 if not (np.all(err_w1 == 0) and np.all(err_w2 == 0)): 00467 raise ValueError("The walker constellations cannot be propagated successfully on the defined time grid") 00468 # Position vector for Walker constellation satellites, motherships and rovers) 00469 cum_pos = np.concatenate((pos_w1,pos_w2, self.pos_m, pos_r)) 00470 return cum_pos 00471 00472 def fitness(self, x, verbose=False): 00473 """Evaluate the fitness of the decision variables. 00474 00475 Args: 00476 x (list): chromosome describing the New Mars communications infrastructure 00477 verbose (bool): If True, print some info. 00478 00479 Returns: 00480 float: fitness for average shortest path 00481 float: fitness for total number of satellites 00482 float: constraint for rover positioning 00483 """ 00484 # Construct the Walker constellations based on input chromosome 00485 walker1, walker2 = self.construct_walkers(x) 00486 # Extract the quality factors and the number of satellites in the Walkers 00487 _,_,_,_,eta1,_,_,_,_,eta2,S1,P1,_,S2,P2,_,_,_,_,_ = x 00488 N1 = S1 * P1 00489 N2 = S2 * P2 00490 # Extract the rover indices from the input chromosome 00491 rovers_idx = np.array(x[-4:]).astype(int) 00492 # Look up latitude and longitudes corresponding to rover indices 00493 lambda0 = self.lambdas[rovers_idx] 00494 phi0 = self.phis[rovers_idx] 00495 # Construct the rover positions 00496 rovers = construct_rover_pos(lambda0, phi0, self.n_rovers, self.jds, self.R_p, self.w_p) 00497 # Concatenate the position of the Walkers, motherships and rover 00498 cum_pos = self.construct_pos(walker1, walker2, rovers) 00499 00500 # Evaluating the fitness function 00501 if verbose: 00502 print("FITNESS EVALUATION:") 00503 00504 # First objective (minimize): 00505 # Compute the average shortest path between any mothership-rover pair 00506 # Iterate over epochs 00507 f1 = 0 00508 nf1 = 34 # f1 normalization factor 00509 d_sat_min_ep = np.inf 00510 for ep_idx in range(1, self.n_epochs): 00511 # Constructs the graph: 00512 # Nodes: Walker sats + motherships + rovers 00513 # Edges: LOS communication 00514 G, _, d_sat_min = self.build_graph(ep_idx, cum_pos, N1, (eta1, eta2)) 00515 if d_sat_min < d_sat_min_ep: 00516 d_sat_min_ep = d_sat_min 00517 f1 += self.average_shortest_path(G, self.n_motherships, self.n_rovers) 00518 00519 # Average over the number of epochs 00520 f1 /= (self.n_epochs - 1) 00521 00522 # Second objective (minimize): 00523 # Compute the total number of satellites (weighted by the quality factors) 00524 f2 = eta1 * N1 + eta2 * N2 00525 nf2 = 100000 # f2 normalization factor 00526 00527 # Constraints: 00528 # The minimum distance between any two rovers needs to be at least 3000km 00529 # to ensure good coverage of the surface of New Mars 00530 min_rover_d, d_rover_min = self.get_rover_constraint(lambda0, phi0) 00531 # The minimum distance between any two nodes of the graph across all epochs 00532 # needs to be at least 50km to ensure a collision-free communications network 00533 min_sat_d = self.get_sat_constraint(d_sat_min_ep) 00534 00535 # Additional information on the fitness of the input chromosome 00536 if verbose: 00537 print(100 * "-") 00538 print("RESULTS:") 00539 print("Total number of satellites (W1: {}, W2: {}): {}".format(N1, N2, N1+N2)) 00540 print("OBJECTIVE #1 - Average communications cost: {}".format(f1/nf1)) 00541 print("OBJECTIVE #2 - Cost of infrastructure: {}".format(f2/nf2)) 00542 print("CONSTRAINT - Minimum distance between rovers ({}): {} km".format("NOK" if min_rover_d > 0 else "OK", d_rover_min)) 00543 print("CONSTRAINT - Minimum distance between sats ({}): {} km".format("NOK" if min_sat_d > 0 else "OK", d_sat_min_ep)) 00544 print(100 * "-") 00545 return [f1/nf1, f2/nf2, min_rover_d, min_sat_d] 00546 00547 def pretty(self, x): 00548 """A verbose evaluation of the fitness functions 00549 00550 Args: 00551 x (list): chromosome describing the New Mars communications infrastructure 00552 00553 Returns: 00554 float: fitness for average shortest path 00555 float: fitness for total number of satellites 00556 float: constraint for rover positioning 00557 float: constraint for satellite positioning 00558 """ 00559 f1, f2, c1, c2 = self.fitness(x, verbose=True) 00560 return f1, f2, c1, c2 00561 00562 def example(self, verbose=False): 00563 """A random chromosome example for the constellation optimization 00564 00565 Returns: 00566 list: a valid chromosome representing a possible constellation design 00567 """ 00568 if verbose: 00569 print("CHROMOSOME:") 00570 print("x = [a1, e1, i1, w1, eta1] + [a2, e2, i2, w2, eta2] + [S1, P1, F1] + [S2, P2, F2] + [r1, r2, r3, r4]") 00571 print(100 * "-") 00572 print("a1: float representing the normalized semi-major axis of Walker1 satellite orbits (in km) [1.05,1.8]") 00573 print("e1: float representing the eccentricity [0, 0.1]") 00574 print("i1: float representing the inclination [0, pi]") 00575 print("w1: float representing the argument of the perigee [0, 2pi]") 00576 print("eta1: float defined as the quality indicator of satellites in the first walker constellation [0, 100]") 00577 print(100 * "-") 00578 print("a2: float representing the normalized semi-major axis of Walker2 satellite orbits (in km) [2.0,3.5]") 00579 print("e2: float representing the eccentricity [0, 0.1]") 00580 print("i2: float representing the inclination [0, pi]") 00581 print("w2: float representing the argument of the perigee [0, 2pi]") 00582 print("eta2: float defined as the quality indicator of satellites in the first walker constellation [0, 100]") 00583 print(100 * "-") 00584 print("S1: integer corresponding to the number of satellites per plane [4, 10]") 00585 print("P1: integer corresponding to the number of planes [2, 10]") 00586 print("F1: integer defining the phasing of the constellation [0, 9]") 00587 print(100 * "-") 00588 print("S2: integer corresponding to the number of satellites per plane [4, 10]") 00589 print("P2: integer corresponding to the number of planes [2, 10]") 00590 print("F2: integer defining the phasing of the constellation [0, 9]") 00591 print(100 * "-") 00592 print("r1: index of rover 1 [0, 99]") 00593 print("r2: index of rover 2 [0, 99]") 00594 print("r3: index of rover 3 [0, 99]") 00595 print("r4: index of rover 4 [0, 99]") 00596 print(100 * "-") 00597 00598 return [1.8, 0.0, 1.2, 0.0, 55.0] + [2.3, 0.0, 1.2, 0.0, 15.0] + [10, 2, 1] + [10, 2, 1] + [13, 21, 34, 55] 00599 00600 def compute_orbit_walker(self, walker, ep0, sma): 00601 """Compute one full-orbit of the Walker constellation planes (for plots) 00602 00603 Args: 00604 walker (sgp4.SatrecArray): the array of Walker satellites to plot 00605 ep0 (float): Julian date denoting starting epoch 00606 sma (float): semi-major axis of orbit 00607 00608 Returns: 00609 pos (numpy array, P x N x 3): N orbital x, y, z positions for P planes 00610 """ 00611 00612 # Extract mean motion 00613 mean_motion = np.sqrt(pk.MU_EARTH / sma**3 / pk.EARTH_RADIUS**3) * 24 * 60 * 60 / (2 * np.pi) 00614 # Compute time range for one full orbit 00615 jds = np.linspace(ep0, ep0 + 1 / mean_motion, 100) 00616 frs = jds * 0.0 00617 # Propagate using SGP4 00618 err, pos, _ = walker.sgp4(jds, frs) 00619 if not np.all(err == 0): 00620 raise ValueError("The satellite cannot be propagated successfully on the defined time grid") 00621 00622 return pos 00623 00624 def compute_orbit_motherships(self, ep0): 00625 """Compute one full-orbit of the motherships from epoch ep0 (for plots) 00626 00627 Args: 00628 ep0 (float): Julian date denoting starting epoch 00629 00630 Returns: 00631 orbits (numpy array, S x N x 3): N orbital x, y, z positions for S satellites 00632 """ 00633 00634 # Pre-allocate return array 00635 N = 100 # number of samples along orbit 00636 # Get SGP4-ready motherships 00637 motherships = get_mothership_satellites() 00638 orbits = np.zeros((len(motherships), N, 3)) 00639 for i, usr in enumerate(motherships): 00640 # Extract mean motion 00641 mean_motion = usr.no_kozai * 24 * 60 / (2 * np.pi) # revolutions per day 00642 # Compute time range for one full orbit 00643 jds = np.linspace(ep0, ep0 + 1 / mean_motion, N) 00644 frs = jds * 0.0 00645 # Propagate using SGP4 00646 err, pos, _ = usr.sgp4_array(jds, frs) 00647 if not np.all(err == 0): 00648 raise ValueError("The satellite cannot be propagated successfully on the defined time grid") 00649 orbits[i] = pos 00650 00651 return orbits 00652 00653 def plot(self, x, src, dst, ep=1, lims=10000, ax=None, dark_mode=True): 00654 """Plot the full constellations with solution path and optional orbits 00655 00656 Args: 00657 x (list): chromosome describing the communications network 00658 src (int): mothership index denoting path source 00659 dst (int): rover index denoting path destination 00660 ep (int): index of the epoch in the predefined time grid 00661 lims (float, optional): plot limits. Defaults to 10000. 00662 ax (matplotlib 3D axis, optional): plot axis. 00663 dark_mode (bool, optional): dark background for plot (recommended) 00664 00665 Returns: 00666 matplotlib.axis: the 3D plot axes 00667 list: indices of the graph nodes on the communications path (if one is found, otherwise []) 00668 """ 00669 00670 # Create the plotting axis if needed 00671 if ax is None: 00672 fig = plt.figure() 00673 ax = fig.add_subplot(projection='3d') 00674 00675 # Apply a dark background for better visualization 00676 if dark_mode: 00677 sns.set(style="darkgrid") 00678 plt.style.use("dark_background") 00679 00680 # Construct the two Walker constellations from the specifications 00681 walker1, walker2 = self.construct_walkers(x) 00682 # Construct the rover positions 00683 rovers_idx = np.array(x[-4:]).astype(int) 00684 lambda0 = self.lambdas[rovers_idx] 00685 phi0 = self.phis[rovers_idx] 00686 rovers = construct_rover_pos(lambda0, phi0, self.n_rovers, self.jds, self.R_p, self.w_p) 00687 # Construct the Walker satellite positions 00688 pos = self.construct_pos(walker1, walker2, rovers) 00689 # Compute and plot the orbits of the Walker and mothership satellites at the epoch ep 00690 # Walker 1 00691 N1 = x[10] * x[11] 00692 w1_orb = self.compute_orbit_walker(walker1, self.jds[ep], x[0]) 00693 for i in range(N1): 00694 ax.plot(w1_orb[i, :, 0], w1_orb[i, :, 1], w1_orb[i, :, 2], 'r-', linewidth=0.5) 00695 # Walker 2 00696 N2 = x[13] * x[14] 00697 w2_orb = self.compute_orbit_walker(walker2, self.jds[ep], x[5]) 00698 for i in range(N2): 00699 ax.plot(w2_orb[i, :, 0], w2_orb[i, :, 1], w2_orb[i, :, 2], 'b-', linewidth=0.5) 00700 # Motherships 00701 mothership_orb = self.compute_orbit_motherships(self.jds[ep]) 00702 for i in range(len(mothership_orb)): 00703 ax.plot(mothership_orb[i, :, 0], mothership_orb[i, :, 1], mothership_orb[i, :, 2], 'w-', linewidth=0.5) 00704 00705 # Overlay the Walker satellite and mothership positions at epoch ep 00706 # Walker1: red, Walker2: blue, motherships: white, rovers: yellow 00707 ax.scatter(pos[:len(walker1),ep,0], pos[:len(walker1),ep,1], pos[:len(walker1),ep,2], c='r', marker="1", s=200) 00708 ax.scatter(pos[len(walker1):-self.n_motherships-self.n_rovers,ep,0], pos[len(walker1):-self.n_motherships-self.n_rovers,ep,1], pos[len(walker1):-self.n_motherships-self.n_rovers,ep,2], c='b', marker="1", s=200) 00709 ax.scatter(pos[-self.n_motherships-self.n_rovers:-self.n_rovers,ep,0], pos[-self.n_motherships-self.n_rovers:-self.n_rovers,ep,1], pos[-self.n_motherships-self.n_rovers:-self.n_rovers,ep,2], c='w', marker="1", s=300) 00710 # Annotate source nodes (motherships) 00711 for i in range(self.n_motherships): 00712 ax.text(pos[-self.n_motherships-self.n_rovers+i,ep,0], pos[-self.n_motherships-self.n_rovers+i,ep,1], pos[-self.n_motherships-self.n_rovers+i,ep,2], '%s' % (str(i+1)), size=20, zorder=1, color='w') 00713 00714 # Annotate destination nodes (rovers) 00715 ax.scatter(pos[-self.n_rovers:,ep,0], pos[-self.n_rovers:,ep,1], pos[-self.n_rovers:,ep,2], c='y', marker="^", s=200) 00716 for i in range(self.n_rovers): 00717 ax.text(pos[-self.n_rovers+i,ep,0], pos[-self.n_rovers+i,ep,1], pos[-self.n_rovers+i,ep,2], '%s' % (str(i+1)), size=20, zorder=1, color='y') 00718 00719 # Build the communications network 00720 path = [] 00721 eta1, eta2 = x[4], x[9] 00722 G, _, _ = self.build_graph(ep, pos, N1, (eta1, eta2)) 00723 N = len(G) 00724 src_node = N1 + N2 + src - 1 00725 dst_node = N1 + N2 + self.n_motherships + dst - 1 00726 # Find the shortest path (if one exists) 00727 try: 00728 path = nx.shortest_path(G, src_node, dst_node, weight="weight", method="dijkstra") 00729 for i,j in zip(path[:-1], path[1:]): 00730 ax.plot([pos[i,ep,0], pos[j,ep,0]], [pos[i,ep,1], pos[j,ep,1]], [pos[i,ep,2], pos[j,ep,2]], 'g-.', linewidth=3) 00731 print("Mothership {} (node {}) communicates with rover {} (node {}) at epoch {} via: {}".format(\ 00732 src, src_node, dst, dst_node, ep, path)) 00733 except nx.exception.NetworkXNoPath as e: 00734 print("Mothership {} (node {}) cannot reach rover {} (node {}) at epoch {}".format(\ 00735 src, src_node, dst, dst_node, ep)) 00736 00737 # Plot the New Mars planet 00738 r = pk.EARTH_RADIUS/1000 00739 u, v = np.mgrid[0:2 * np.pi:30j, 0:np.pi:20j] 00740 x = r * np.cos(u) * np.sin(v) 00741 y = r * np.sin(u) * np.sin(v) 00742 z = r * np.cos(v) 00743 ax.plot_surface(x, y, z, alpha=0.3, color="purple", linewidth=0) 00744 ax.set_axis_off() 00745 ax.set_xlim(-lims,lims) 00746 ax.set_ylim(-lims,lims) 00747 ax.set_zlim(-lims,lims) 00748 ax.set_box_aspect([ub - lb for lb, ub in (getattr(ax, f'get_{a}lim')() for a in 'xyz')]) 00749 return ax, path 00750 00751 def combine_scores(points): 00752 """ Function for aggregating single solutions into one score using hypervolume indicator """ 00753 00754 ref_point = np.array([1.2, 1.4]) 00755 00756 # solutions that not dominate the reference point are excluded 00757 filtered_points = [s[:2] for s in points if pg.pareto_dominance(s[:2], ref_point)] 00758 00759 if len(filtered_points) == 0: 00760 return 0.0 00761 else: 00762 hv = pg.hypervolume(filtered_points) 00763 #return -hv.computborderse(ref_point) * 10000 00764 return -hv.compute(ref_point) * 10000 00765 00766 00767 import warnings 00768 warnings.filterwarnings("ignore") 00769 00770 from fcmaes.optimizer import wrapper, dtime, Bite_cpp, De_cpp, Crfmnes_cpp 00771 import fcmaes 00772 from fcmaes import retry, mode, modecpp, moretry, mapelites, diversifier 00773 from scipy.optimize import Bounds 00774 from os import walk 00775 import multiprocessing as mp 00776 import ctypes as ct 00777 from functools import partial 00778 from fcmaes import bitecpp 00779 from multiprocessing import Manager 00780 00781 udp = constellation_udp() 00782 nobj = 2 00783 ncon = 2 00784 dim = 20 00785 ref_point = np.array([1.2, 1.4]) 00786 ubs = udp.get_bounds() 00787 bounds = Bounds(ubs[0], ubs[1]) 00788 00789 def fitness(x): # fitness wrapper converting the last ten arguments into integer values 00790 x[10:] = x[10:].astype(int) 00791 return np.array(udp.fitness(x)) 00792 00793 def select_valid(xs, ys): 00794 cv = np.array([np.amax(y[nobj:], 0) for y in ys]) 00795 valid = (cv <= 0) 00796 ys = ys.T[:nobj].T 00797 ys = ys[valid] 00798 xs = xs[valid] 00799 xs, ys = moretry.pareto(xs, ys) 00800 return xs, ys 00801 00802 def read_solution(fname): 00803 with np.load(fname) as data: 00804 xs = data['xs'] 00805 ys = data['ys'] 00806 return xs, ys 00807 00808 from fcmaes.evaluator import parallel_mo 00809 00810 #+++++++ Apply fcmaes multi objective optimization using NSGA-II population update ++++++++++++++++++++++++ 00811 # Uses fcmaes multi objective optimization to optimize the pareto front 00812 # Uses parallel function evaluation, but cannot pass score 6400 even when executed many times, 00813 # using a large number of iterations and a big population. 00814 # Which is the reason only one team - "ML Actonauts" achieved this goal during the GECCO competition 00815 # https://www.esa.int/gsp/ACT/projects/spoc-2023/ 00816 00817 def mo_par(): 00818 00819 guess = None 00820 #guess, _ = read_solution("res/quantcomm_1_100_6372134.npz") # inject an existing pareto front 00821 popsize = 512 00822 00823 es = mode.MODE(nobj, ncon, bounds, popsize = popsize, nsga_update=True) # Python MOO optimizer 00824 #es = modecpp.MODE_C(nobj, ncon, bounds, popsize = popsize, nsga_update=True) # C++ MOO optimizer 00825 00826 fit = parallel_mo(fitness, nobj+ncon, workers = mp.cpu_count()) 00827 iters = 0 00828 stop = 0 00829 max_hv = 0 00830 time_0 = time.perf_counter() 00831 if not guess is None: 00832 es.set_guess(guess, fitness) 00833 00834 while stop == 0 and iters < 100000: 00835 xs = es.ask() 00836 ys = fit(xs) 00837 es.tell(ys) # tell evaluated x 00838 iters += 1 00839 valid = [y[:2] for y in ys if np.less_equal(y , np.array([1.2, 1.4, 0, 0])).all()] 00840 hv = pg.hypervolume(valid).compute(ref_point) 00841 if hv > max_hv: 00842 max_hv = hv 00843 if hv > 0.9999*max_hv: # show stagnation 00844 logger.info(f'time: {dtime(time_0)} iter: {iters} hv: {hv * 10000}') 00845 np.savez_compressed("quantcomm_" + str(int(hv * 1000000)), xs=xs, ys=ys) 00846 fit.stop() 00847 return xs, ys 00848 00849 #+++++++ Apply fcmaes diversifier quality diversity algorithm ++++++++++++++++++++++++ 00850 # The initial archive is created using an existing pareto front. This way the QD-algorithm 00851 # dosn't need to find this "hard to reach" area of the solution space by its own. 00852 00853 def mo_to_qd(y): 00854 f1, f2, c1, c2 = y 00855 # weight the objectives and constraints 00856 return f1/0.5 + f2/1.4 + c1/3000 + c2/50, \ 00857 np.minimum(ref_point, np.array([f1, f2])) # use the objectives as descriptive space 00858 00859 def qd_fun(x): 00860 return mo_to_qd(fitness(x)) # convert the MO result into a QD result 00861 00862 def get_arch(qd_bounds, niche_num, samples_per_niche): 00863 xs, _ = read_solution("res/quantcomm_1_100_6372134.npz") # inject an existing pareto front 00864 arch = mapelites.empty_archive(dim, qd_bounds, niche_num, samples_per_niche) 00865 mapelites.update_archive(arch, xs, qd_fun) 00866 return arch 00867 00868 def nd_par(niche_num = 10000): 00869 udp = constellation_udp() 00870 ubs = udp.get_bounds() 00871 qd_bounds = Bounds([0.7, 0.], [1.2, 1.4]) 00872 samples_per_niche = 20 00873 arch = get_arch(qd_bounds, niche_num, samples_per_niche) 00874 opt_params0 = {'solver':'elites', 'popsize':100, 'use':2} 00875 opt_params1 = {'solver':'CRMFNES_CPP', 'max_evals':2000, 'popsize':32, 'stall_criterion':3} 00876 archive = diversifier.minimize( 00877 mapelites.wrapper(qd_fun, 2, interval=10000, save_interval=100000), 00878 bounds, qd_bounds, 00879 workers = 32, opt_params=[opt_params0, opt_params1], archive = arch, 00880 niche_num = niche_num, samples_per_niche = samples_per_niche, 00881 max_evals = 1000000) 00882 00883 print('final archive:', archive.info()) 00884 archive.save('final archive') 00885 00886 00887 #++++++++++++++++++++++ Apply BiteOpt Single-Objective Optimization ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ 00888 # Uses https://github.com/avaneev/biteopt applied to a fitness function maximizing the hypervolume 00889 # to find the best target_num solutions maximizing the pareto front 00890 # Easily surpasses score 6400 when given enough time. The final result needs to be reduced to 100 solutions. 00891 00892 def so_par(): 00893 00894 target_num = 512 # desired size of the pareto front 00895 00896 # hypervolume replacing one solution of the pareto front 00897 def fit_hyper(i, ys, x): 00898 y = fitness(x) 00899 c = sum([10000 + c for c in y[2:] if c > 0]) 00900 if c > 0: # constraint violation 00901 return c 00902 if pg.pareto_dominance(y[:2], ref_point): 00903 ys[i] = y[:2] 00904 return -pg.hypervolume(ys).compute(ref_point) * 10000 00905 else: 00906 return 0 00907 00908 # parallel optimization of the whole pareto front 00909 class OptSo(object): 00910 00911 def __init__(self, 00912 max_evals, 00913 xs, 00914 ys 00915 ): 00916 self.max_evals = max_evals 00917 self.manager = Manager() 00918 self.ys = self.manager.list(ys) 00919 self.ys0 = list(ys) 00920 self.xs = self.manager.list(xs) 00921 self.min_ys = np.amin(ys, axis=0) 00922 self.count = mp.RawValue(ct.c_int, 0) 00923 self.mutex = mp.Lock() 00924 self.n = len(ys) 00925 00926 def incr(self): 00927 with self.mutex: 00928 next = self.count.value 00929 self.count.value += 1 00930 return next 00931 00932 def eval(self, workers=mp.cpu_count()): 00933 proc=[mp.Process(target=self.eval_loop) for pid in range(workers)] 00934 [p.start() for p in proc] 00935 [p.join() for p in proc] 00936 return np.array(self.xs), np.array(self.ys) 00937 00938 def eval_loop(self): 00939 while True: 00940 i = self.incr() 00941 if i >= self.n: 00942 return 00943 logger.info(f'optimizing solution {i}') 00944 fit = wrapper(partial(fit_hyper, i, list(self.ys))) 00945 x0 = self.xs[i] 00946 ret = bitecpp.minimize(fit, bounds, x0, max_evaluations = self.max_evals) 00947 if ret.fun < 0: # no constraint violation? 00948 y = fitness(ret.x)[:2] 00949 self.ys[i] = y 00950 self.xs[i] = ret.x 00951 00952 def opt_so(max_evals, xs, ys, workers=mp.cpu_count()): 00953 eval = OptSo(max_evals, xs, ys) 00954 return eval.eval(workers) 00955 00956 max_evals = 2000 00957 00958 # random initialization 00959 # rg = Generator(MT19937()) 00960 # xs = [rg.uniform(ubs[0], ubs[1]) for _ in range(target_num)] 00961 # ys = [ref_point-0.000001 for _ in range(target_num)] 00962 00963 # initialization with a given pareto front 00964 xs, ys = read_solution("res/quantcomm_1_100_6372134.npz") # inject an existing pareto front 00965 00966 last_xs = [] 00967 last_ys = [] 00968 for i in range(1, 1000): 00969 xs, ys = opt_so(max_evals, xs, ys) 00970 xs, ys = moretry.pareto(np.array(list(xs) + last_xs), 00971 np.array(list(ys) + last_ys)) 00972 if len(ys) > target_num: 00973 xs, ys = reduce(xs, ys, target_num) 00974 hv = int(pg.hypervolume(ys).compute(ref_point) * 10000000) 00975 00976 np.savez_compressed("quantcomm_" + str(i) + "_" + str(len(ys)) + "_" 00977 + str(max_evals) + "_" + str(hv), xs=xs, ys=ys) 00978 last_xs = list(xs) 00979 last_ys = list(ys) 00980 00981 return xs 00982 00983 00984 #++++++++++++++++++++++ Apply PYMOO NSGA-II ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ 00985 # Uses PYMOO and https://github.com/avaneev/biteopt to find the best target_num solutions 00986 # maximizing the pareto front. 00987 # Easily surpasses score 6400 when given enough time. The result is already reduced to 100 solutions. 00988 # Note that instead of relying on PYMOOs parallelization mechanisms (partial) optimization runs 00989 # are executed in parallel achieving maximal scaling with the number of cores. 00990 # The fitness function is "hijacked" collecting solutions later joined for the resulting pareto front. 00991 00992 def pymoo_par(): 00993 00994 from pymoo.core.problem import ElementwiseProblem 00995 from pymoo.algorithms.moo.nsga2 import NSGA2 00996 from pymoo.termination import get_termination 00997 from pymoo.operators.crossover.sbx import SBX 00998 from pymoo.operators.mutation.pm import PM 00999 from pymoo.operators.sampling.rnd import FloatRandomSampling 01000 from pymoo.constraints.eps import AdaptiveEpsilonConstraintHandling 01001 from pymoo.optimize import minimize 01002 from itertools import chain 01003 01004 target_num = 100 # desired size of the pareto front 01005 n_eval = 10000 01006 popsize = 300 01007 time_0 = time.perf_counter() 01008 guess = None 01009 guess, ys = read_solution("res/quantcomm_1_100_6372134.npz") # inject an existing pareto front 01010 guess, ys = reduce(guess, ys, target_num) 01011 01012 class fitness_wrapper(): 01013 01014 def __init__(self, 01015 pid, 01016 xs_out, 01017 ys_out 01018 ): 01019 self.max_hv = 0 01020 self.xs = [] 01021 self.ys = [] 01022 self.count = 1 01023 self.evals = 0 01024 self.pid = pid 01025 self.xs_out = xs_out 01026 self.ys_out = ys_out 01027 01028 # fitness accumulates valid solutions and monitors their hypervolume 01029 def __call__(self, x): 01030 y = fitness(x) 01031 self.evals += 1 01032 if np.amax(y[2:]) <= 0 and np.less_equal(y[:2], ref_point).all() : # add only valid solutions 01033 self.ys.append(y[:2]) # exclude constraint values because solution is valid 01034 self.xs.append(x) 01035 if len(self.ys) >= 2*popsize: 01036 self.count += 1 01037 xs, ys = moretry.pareto(np.array(self.xs), np.array(self.ys)) # reduce to pareto front 01038 self.xs, self.ys = list(xs), list(ys) 01039 hv = pg.hypervolume(self.ys).compute(ref_point) 01040 if hv > self.max_hv * 1.0001: # significant improvement: register solutions at managed dicts 01041 self.max_hv = hv 01042 self.xs_out[self.pid] = self.xs 01043 self.ys_out[self.pid] = self.ys 01044 logger.info(f'time: {dtime(time_0)} ev: {self.evals} hv: {hv * 10000} n: {len(ys)}') 01045 return y 01046 01047 class OptPymoo(object): 01048 01049 def eval_loop(self, workers=mp.cpu_count()): 01050 xs = guess 01051 for i in range(1, 1000): 01052 xs, ys = self.eval(i, xs, workers) 01053 return xs, ys 01054 01055 def eval(self, i, guess, workers): 01056 manager = Manager() 01057 xs_out = manager.dict() # for inter process communication 01058 ys_out = manager.dict() # collects solutions generated in the sub processes 01059 fits = [fitness_wrapper(pid, xs_out, ys_out) for pid in range(workers)] 01060 proc=[mp.Process(target=self.optimize, args=(guess, fits[pid], pid)) for pid in range(workers)] 01061 [p.start() for p in proc] # spawn NSGAII optimization workers 01062 [p.join() for p in proc] 01063 xs = np.array(list(chain.from_iterable(xs_out.values()))) # join collected solutions 01064 ys = np.array(list(chain.from_iterable(ys_out.values()))) # we ignore the pymoo optimization result 01065 xs, ys = moretry.pareto(xs, ys) 01066 if len(ys) > target_num: 01067 xs, ys = reduce(xs, ys, target_num) 01068 hv = int(pg.hypervolume(ys).compute(ref_point) * 10000000) 01069 np.savez_compressed("quantcomm_" + str(i) + "_" + str(len(ys)) + 01070 "_" + str(hv), xs=xs, ys=ys) 01071 return xs, ys 01072 01073 def optimize(self, guess, fit, pid): 01074 01075 class MyProblem(ElementwiseProblem): 01076 01077 def __init__(self, **kwargs): 01078 super().__init__(n_var=dim, 01079 n_obj=nobj, 01080 n_constr=ncon, 01081 xl=np.array(bounds.lb), 01082 xu=np.array(bounds.ub), **kwargs) 01083 01084 def _evaluate(self, x, out, *args, **kwargs): 01085 y = fit(x) 01086 out["F"] = y[:nobj] 01087 out["G"] = y[nobj:] 01088 01089 problem = MyProblem() 01090 algorithm = NSGA2( 01091 pop_size=popsize, 01092 n_offsprings=10, 01093 sampling=FloatRandomSampling() if guess is None else guess, 01094 crossover=SBX(prob=0.9, eta=15), # simulated binary crossover 01095 mutation=PM(eta=20), # polynomial mutation 01096 eliminate_duplicates=True, 01097 ) 01098 algorithm = AdaptiveEpsilonConstraintHandling(algorithm, perc_eps_until=0.5) 01099 minimize(problem, algorithm, get_termination("n_eval", n_eval), verbose=False, seed=pid*677) 01100 01101 opt = OptPymoo() 01102 return opt.eval_loop() 01103 01104 #++++++++++++++++++++++ Reduction to 100 solutions ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ 01105 # Uses https://github.com/avaneev/biteopt / parallel optimization to find the best num solutions 01106 # maximizing the pareto front 01107 01108 def reduce(xs, ys, num, evals = 50000, retries = mp.cpu_count()): 01109 if len(ys) <= num: 01110 return xs, ys 01111 bounds = Bounds([0]*num, [len(ys)-1E-9]*num) # select best num from xs, ys 01112 01113 def fit(x): # selects 100 solutions and returns the negated pareto front of this selection 01114 selected = x.astype(int) 01115 ys_sel = ys[selected] 01116 hv = pg.hypervolume(ys_sel) 01117 return -hv.compute(ref_point) * 10000 01118 01119 res = fcmaes.retry.minimize(wrapper(fit), # parallel optimization restart / retry 01120 bounds, 01121 optimizer=Bite_cpp(evals), 01122 num_retries=retries) 01123 01124 selected = res.x.astype(int) 01125 return xs[selected], ys[selected] 01126 01127 if __name__ == '__main__': 01128 01129 #pymoo_par() 01130 #so_par() 01131 mo_par() 01132 #nd_par() 01133
